OctoPrint

Print anything from anywhere.

Created & Maintained by Gina Häußge

The responsive web interface for your 3D printer

Control your printer

Start, pause and stop print jobs, remotely move the print head along all axes, extrude, retract or just define your own custom controls.

Monitor your prints

Get constant feedback regarding the current progress of your print job, your printer's extrusion and bed temperature and even a live webcam feed.

Create timelapse movies

Automatically create a timelapse of your prints -- triggered by layer change or time -- and have it rendered into a finished movie.

Make your printer wireless

Connect you printer to a small embedded and WiFi enabled device such as the popular Raspberry Pi, install OctoPrint on it and you have an instant wireless printer.

Manage your gcode

With OctoPrint's built-in gcode management you can manage your ready-to-print gcode files within the host software, including printing stats and gcode analysis results.

Visualize your gcode

OctoPrint incorporates the awesome gCodeVisualizer by Alexey Ustyantsev which allows you to visualize your gcode files before and even during printjobs.

Free as in beer

OctoPrint is free and open source software released under the Affero General Public License (AGPL).

Highly compatible

OctoPrint has been proven to work with many different printer electronics and firmwares. Give it a try!

Constantly updated

Thanks to its active community OctoPrint is constantly updated, with new features added regularly.

... and more to come!

About

OctoPrint is a so called host software for 3D printers. It is the kind of software you need in order to control your 3D printer and send it the actual commands to do its job. Other tools for this task include Printrun, Repetier Host and also Cura.

OctoPrint differs from existing host solutions in that its major focus is to provide a web interface that allows controlling the printer remotely from anywhere on the network or even the internet while offering the same responsiveness and feedback options available on native host applications like the ones listed above. In order to achieve this, OctoPrint makes heavy use of current web technologies and frameworks, such as AJAX, HTML5 web sockets and data binding via Knockout.js.

OctoPrint was developed to be run on small embedded devices such as the popular Raspberry Pi, thus paving an easy and cheap path to make your existing 3D printer WiFi enabled and untether it from your laptop or work station.

Credit where credit is due

OctoPrint started out as a fork of Cura for adding a web interface to its printing functionality and was originally named "Printer WebUI". It still uses large parts of Cura's communication code for talking to the printer, but has been reorganized to only include those parts of Cura necessary for its targeted use case.

It also uses the following libraries and frameworks for backend and frontend:

  • Flask
  • Tornado
  • Tornadio2
  • PyYAML
  • Socket.io
  • jQuery
  • Bootstrap
  • Font Awesome
  • Knockout.js
  • Underscore.js
  • Flot
  • jQuery File Upload
  • Pines Notify
  • gCodeVisualizer
For webcam support on the Raspberry Pi I recommend MJPG-Streamer.

I also want to thank Janina Himmen for providing the kick-ass logo!

Why is it called OctoPrint and what's with the crystal ball in the logo?

It so happens that I needed a favicon and also OctoPrint's first name -- Printer WebUI -- simply lacked a certain coolness to it. So I asked The Internet(tm) for advise. After some brainstorming, the idea of a cute Octopus watching his print job remotely through a crystal ball was born... or something like that.

Screenshots

The temperature graph and controls

The graph is continuously updated and gives feedback about the current and target temperatures of extruder and (optional) printbed.

Embedded webcam view and timelapse settings

The gcode viewer

It offers you a layer-by-layer view of the currently selected GCODE file and also updates live during printing to show the currently executed GCODE commands.

Controls for jogging, extrusion, retraction, motor and fan control

Additionally to the pictured default controls it's possible to define custom controls via the configuration.

Gcode management

Uploaded gcode files are analyzed and can be sorted and filtered. Since file analysis is quite CPU intense, OctoPrint makes sure to perform it only when the system is not currently busy with printing.

The Terminal tab

It shows you the last 300 lines of communication with the printer and allows you to send manual commands to the printer.

The Settings dialog

It allows you the configuration of most of the software's options.
